reviewText:
I played for 15 hours on normal, completing the main quest with one ending, and the majority of the side quests. I used the XBOX 360 controller to play the game.

I can only recommend the game on sale, and if you don’t have any high expectations. You might be disappointed otherwise, like I was. I was more disappointed in the plot and characters as I got nearer to the end of the game.

Mars: War Logs (MWL) starts off great but will eventually fall flat and dull, with boring characters, story, and environments. RPG elements are great, and combat gets more interesting if you invest the points wisely. MWL looks good on top that helps immersion, unfortunately on closer inspection npcs and the environment look rough around the edges. MWL has a very linear corridor setup for you to travel around, and visually the game gets very repetitive.

MWL does start with an interesting story, and characters. Mars itself has a robust background that really helps create immersion in the game, the same can be said for the characters, but it doesn’t last. The story feels uninspired nearer the end of the game, and characters feel rushed, flat, and placed to connect the plot. This is a shame because Spiders have done a really good job in creating the universe you play in, they just couldn’t hold it up.

Your introduction to the protagonist, Roy Temperance is a little odd, as he doesn't react to the situation he’s in. He just stands there in silence, and the gang leader he’s confronting has a one way conversation with him. I understand that maybe the reason for this was to make Roy a blank canvas, so you could shape his personality with the conversation lines you pick. However they missed a good opportunity to introduce the conversation mechanic. You can also further shape Roy by either abandoning fallen enemies or killing them at the end of a fight, the payoff is more serum, serum is the game currency as well as a craftable for medicine.

Like a lot of action games the fighting doesn’t get interesting till you unlock certain skills that compliment your play style. The same could be said for MWL, because when you unlock the technomancer skill set, the combat is a lot more fun. You can plan your skill advancements by looking at the locked skills, this really helped gain the skills I wanted on level up.

For everything the combat does right, it does something wrong as well, but at least it gives you options. You can go solo or go along with a side kick. You can control your buddy’s fighting style with defensive/attack nearest/ranged/or same as, but you can’t share items and tell them to use them or certain attacks, also you can’t heal them. Not being able to heal your party member will mean that they could fall during the fight. Mashing buttons won’t help you either, this will end up queuing the next selection while the current action is played out, a little thought and planning is vital to fights. There is the option to go in stealthy and hide enemies to avoid alerting others, your success may depend on your skill unlocks. Combat isn’t helped by bad camera angles, that can have you fighting off screen till it resets or you move it.

From an RPG aspect a lot of game mechanics and details were added that really benefit the game. You can craft upgrades for your melee weapon or clothing, your conversation choices will affect the person you become and the reactions by npcs. Levelling up will give you skill points to use for combat, and in the trait selection. The trait selection offers an additional boost to non combat things such as looting and crafting. Cutscenes can be skipped as well. All these little elements enrich the gameplay and were thought out by an experienced dev team with gaming experience.

Visually MWL looks good on top then degrades the further down you go. Roy Temperance, has a lot of detail and looks good. However thing start to look a little worse when you get to npcs and the environment itself. MWL really needed some variety in how it looks, the change in environment was occasional, but still bland at best.

Hopefully one daySpiders will  revisit Mars, they really do have an impressive backstory with a lot of potential to do more with, especially with the technomancy.

reviewText: At first I really liked this game... but after awhile I couldn't stand the combat system. I basically got out of the first area and then restarted, and tried a new character build. But it's actually the combat system that I can't stand, so I can't play it.\n\nIt uses a similar combat system to the Witcher 2 (attack, block, evade). The problem is that the AI of your companions is useless, if you have any companions, and that if you are fighting two opponents you're guaranteed to lose at rock paper scissors, since one of the two will be countering you, and the other will kill you. That means you're constantly trying to evade and get occasional hits in, in really cramped quarters. It's just not fun combat, at all.

reviewText:
It's like a bioware rpg (jade Empire mostly) with a 10th of the budget, a 20th of the charm and none of the redeeming qualities.

To elaborate (or basically repeat myself), it has what you would expect from an rpg in 2013: a story, a real-time combat system, some companions, some choices and a few consequences, but the game never excels in any of these or gives you any reason why you would want to play this over any bioware games (yes, even those ones).

Wait until The Witcher 2 is cheaper than a fast food boxed meal again if you're one of those weirdos who doesn't have it yet (assuming you want a game containing a story, a real-time combat system, some choices and some consequences).

I found this game to be incredibly good, the story, the characters, and the setting are all very compelling from the first scene, to the end credits. While not an incredibly long game it's well worth playing, and I intend to play through it at least a couple more times. Mars: War Logs is definitely worth the price and I recommend it to anyone looking for a quick, compelling, sci-fi RPG.

reviewText:
Spoiler tags used where necessary.

Quick Review:
Mars: War Logs may have had a very rough start, but the patches and English dialogue overhaul make it a great experience for anyone who enjoys meaningful quests, a believable world, and realistic characters. I clocked in 30 hours before being completely finished with my first playthrough. My only recommendation for anyone considering purchasing it is to watch a gameplay video showing the combat, because it's likely to turn certain people away immediately. Try to play it like a hack & slash and you will die endlessly.

Currently, it has its share of tiny errors that can be easily missed if players aren't looking for them.
To avoid bugs/glitches, update your computer's graphics controller, audio controller, and verify the integrity of game cache before playing.

Computer: Compaq Presario CQ57-439WM Notebook PC
Operating System: Windows 7 Home Premium 64bit
Gamepad: Logitech Dual Action w/Logitech Profiler

In-Depth Review:
//Level Design
The level design is so well thought out that the entire world feels expansive and every location feels like what it is. Mole caves feel like enclosed spaces with only one exit. Shadowlair feels like a city full of life and people going about their lives even if they aren't happy to be alive. The structures above Roy and the paths he isn't allowed to take, even though they are right in front of him, all make the world feel existent.
An hour into the game, the level design reminded me of Phantom Dust. Fourteen hours later, it still did. This isn't a negative trait in the slightest.

//Combat
Combat is challenging, but simple. Attack, guard-break, block, counter, and dodge make up the basic maneuvers. What players spend their skill points on after leveling-up make up the fun part.
Excluding boss fights, players can flee to the next area of a level to skip combat altogether. This could lead to a need for grinding as the game progresses, unfortunately.
The response time prevents button mashing since doing so will prevent players from making the quick decisions that are a constant part of combat. There's basically a half-second delay for every movement Roy makes.
Party members can hold their own, but not for very long. Their main purpose is to distract enemies while the Roy eliminates as many as he can before they inevitably fall unconscious. They cannot be healed by the player, but their health is fully restored at the end of every battle. This system forces players to engage in combat rather than hide and adds an invisible timer set to how long they have until every conscious enemy gangs up on them. Yep.

>Technomancy
The Technomancer skill tree is a worthy investment due to how fun and powerful it is. Too many enemies? Electric Arc. A single enemy with a high armor rating? Charged Weapon. Feeling overwhelmed? Energy Shield. The more you experiment, the more fun you'll have.

>Stealth
Stealth is worth investing in for players who prefer not to go on all-out frontal assaults and enjoy thinning out the enemy first. There are some very tricky levels where playing as a stealth-based character becomes a challenge, but figuring out who to eliminate first and when to do so is part of the fun. Enemies are alerted by fallen comrades and will alert others if players don't quiet them quickly enough. Only further down the Renegade skill tree can players invest in hiding fallen enemies from sight.
Party members stay in place and out the way until Roy exits from stealth mode. Since a patrolling enemy can still spot them, players can push party members wherever they want by running into them.

//Boss Fights
To my recollection, there are six challenging boss fights in the game. None felt misplaced or thrown in.

My only complaint is that, at the final level of the game, there should have been an actual boss fight before the endscene. One or two powerful technomancers that Roy and/or Mary knew from their past would have done the trick.

//Quests
There are more than enough non-mandatory side quests that get players more engulfed in the game world. Not a single quest is dull and pointless. All bring the world together and add character to its many inhabitants.
Quest can go anywhere from helping ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and mutants to stopping serial killers and spying on a political figure. Get ready for some odd situations you may not have been prepared for.

//Party Members
The party members are interesting characters with their own motives, back-stories, and personalities. Personal favorite: Mary. She will say the darnest, hilarious, and most sad things.
Players get a choice between three female love interests and gain five party members total. Only four of these five are available for each playthrough, however, and only one is allowed to accompany Roy at a time.
Party members actually comment on Roy's decisions (serum extraction and dialogue) every now and then. Those moments help breath life into his character and theirs.

//Dialogue
Conversations are well written and funny. There are even references here and there.
Players get different options of what to say to NPC's. Some choices will cause Roy to engage in combat and others will cause him to evade it.
Get ready for some hilarious conversations.
Thanks to the dialogue, I've found myself caring about the characters I met throughout the game. This really backfired when people died.

//Ending
I enjoyed the Aurora ending cutscenes I got, especially the last one.

The endlevel, on the other hand, was lacking in impact. I may have gotten the impression that this was it, but the lack of dialogue during the entire level made it similar to a non-boring grind without the need to level up.
I'll give Spiders this much, they were successful in making a grinding level that was entertaining and barely felt like a grind. Unfortunately, they did not give it thrill, impact, or emotion.
The dialogue between Roy and his follower at the end was great, though. Just one more moment like or leading up to that beforehand would have done the trick for me.

Even having Honour	 speaking out loud about the 'endboss', and adding backstory in the process, would have tremendously helped players care about what happened next. It would have also helped us understand the choice that was made in the first endscene.
It's a matter of character depth. More was given in the endscene for Honour and the 'endboss', but not quite enough. For me, the 'endboss' was the only character who lacked depth. All we really got were the reasons for said character's actions, which make sense and explain his/her villainy.

Other than the lack of impact and a boss, the endlevel was perfectly fine.

//Others
Players must choose one of two factions (Resistance or Aurora) two-thirds of the way through the game. Both come with their own female party member / love interest.

There are multiple opportunities to end some NPC's lives outside of extracting Serum from defeated foes. This includes resolving conflicts for quests and actually killing one of the potential party members either directly or by abandonment.

Serum extracting isn't necessary unless players want to do a 'Dark Side' playthrough, which affects the merchants' prices, intimidation skills of the player, and reactions of party members.

The actual war logs used in the game is a nice touch. It adds first person perspective immersion for those who are interested. Think of the journal from the Elder Scrolls series or, more accurately, Arcanum: Of Steamworks & Magick Obscura.
There's even a bestiary that includes NPCs and locations.

The main menu and combat menu are both very well designed. It took me some time to remember which menu tab (equipment, stats, etc) had what, though.

Weapon, armor, item, and component crafting adds an extra layer of strategy to the game. There are no wrong combinations. It all comes down to what works best for your play style.

reviewText:
This game is a great example of what happens when a developer sets his ambition way too high, and creates something that he is not capable of creating. He might have had great ideas, but because his skill was not that great, he ended up creating something of mediocre worth rather than a grand masterpiece. And what a shame it is, because this game did indeed have some potential.

Gameplay wise, it is essentially Witcher 2 combined with Mass Effect, but without any of the things that made both games great. Much of the choices that you make don't really matter, and the morality system is pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥, as all the bonuses that it gives you don't really help at all, nor does the morality system majorly change the way people look at you. The bonus that you get for being a man with an excellent reputation doesn't help due to how useless your NPC party members are, thanks to the fact that the AI in the game for party members sucks ♥♥♥ and due to how quickly they die. Merchants are pretty useless unless you are trying to complete certain plot related quests that involve giving serum (money) to NPCs by selling off ♥♥♥♥ you don't need or are in need of serum for making meds to use in combat. You can pretty much get a lot of the items you need by looting enemies or by finding some junk piles or crates that are put across the map. Speaking of serum, it is admittedly an interesting kind of currency, but as mentioned before, it's only really useful for those two things, and just like most items, you loot it from crates and enemies. The way you loot it from enemies though is usually through a serum extractor, which apparently kills some guy who should already be dead after being beaten mercilessly by a pipe with a cleaver, and using the serum extractor on a guy who should have already been dead by now also lowers your reputation. Like that totally makes any sense. Had it not been for the skill level cap of three instead of two, it would have been safe to say that the game's skill tree system is an exact rip off of Witcher 2's skill tree. Now, character building is one of the better things about this game, but sadly there still are a couple of problems. For instance, the renegade skill tree has skills that suppossedly help improve the stealth in this game, but stealth is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing useless thanks to how poorly it's implemented. I know Witcher 2 has some questionable stealth as well, but at least that game didn't have you go out of stealth mode after attempting to knock out an enemy or had skills in the skill tree related to a mechanic that was pretty much pointless. The perk system is also pretty stupid. Do X amount of things several times and you can then wait till you level up a few times in order to get X amount of Character Perk Points just to purchase X perk. Why not give the perk after doing X thing several times, or do what the Fallout series does, and give out a perk every few levels. Some perks are also tied to your morality level, which is something that I find to be really stupid. Not being able to use charismatic and intimidative dialogue choices unless your character is (or was at one point) with a good or bad rep shows that the game's view on morality is worse than that of an elementary schooler. Of course, as mentioned before, most of your choices do jack ♥♥♥♥, so what's the point anyways? Combat is pretty much ripped straight from Witcher 2. Everything from the ability to slow down time and switch your skills to the roll n' doge - stab - block gameplay of Witcher 2, with the exception that you can actually heal during combat. It's too bad that the camera can cause you to ♥♥♥♥ up, and although not at the teir of Kingdom Hearts Camera Bad, it still is pretty shoddy. There are also bombs, traps and ranged weapons just like the ones from Witcher 2, but the variety is quite lacking. In fact, you only get one type of trap, one type of gun (a nail gun, which makes me question how they could only have those and not ♥♥♥♥ like machine guns and laser pistols), and one type or bomb. The game also allows you one AI-controlled party member (this is where the Mass Effect elements come in), though you might as well be playing without the AI, because about 95% of the time, I found the AI for party members to be one of the most incompetent things ever, as it dies faster than a still-born baby in the womb, and that's even when you tell it to focus on defense. Not being able to go through your party member's equipment in order to give them better weapons and armor doesn't make it any better. The game is also full of stupid invisible walls, and the enviorments are a bore to explore, as you can only enter places that the game deems important. You cannot even enter a single house that belongs to some random person. The civillian NPCs in the game must be the most ballin' people in the universe, because they don't get scared if you pull out your weapon in front of them! Side quests ♥♥♥♥ing suck, as they are primarilly the same boring fetch quests found in plenty of other RPGs, and their rewards usually aren't worth it. Finally, there's crafting, and cliche as it sounds, crafting is perhaps the game's best feature, though I do find it stupid that you can access the craft screen during battle.


Before I talk about the story, I would like to say that I wouldn't call the setting a cyberpunk one, as it looks more like an apocalyptic low-tech wasteland with some minor cyberpunk and space opera elements rather than a cyberpunk world full of men with cyberarms that act as weapons mowing down corparates from the local mega-corp. Having hi-tech gloves that let you shoot beams of electricity doesn't make it a cyberpunk game either. The game does however have an interesting setting, despite how generic of a setting Mars tends to be. Of course, the game has to have poorly explained lore that is extremely hard to follow, and this is despite the patch that was suppossed to fix a lot of the problems with the script. The characters? I didn't really like any of them, and the way the characters act is so unreal that I highly doubt that anyone could truly care for them. My least favorite charcters would have to either be Roy or Mary. Roy because he's the typical man with a mysterious past type of character, and Mary because she suddenly goes from being this ♥♥♥♥♥ who wants to kill you and hates your guts to this ♥♥♥♥♥ who wants to ♥♥♥♥ you just because you saved her, and she doesn't even have a hint of suspicion about you afterwards.


Presentation wise, the game is what you would expect from a small studio. Not too bad, but there could have been way more colours than just orange, red, black and grey. Character designs range from okay to ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ looking, Mary included. Enviorments tend to be boring as hell, and as mentioned before, are not very explorable due to how many invisible walls there are. The music is pretty forgettable as well. Finally, there's the voice acting, and holy ♥♥♥♥ is it bad most of the time. Sometimes, it's actually quite funny, while other times it's cringe worthy, and of course there's always the mixture of the two. Now, I should note that it is better than the voice acting that was in the game at launch, but it still is a long way from being good.


In conclusion, Mars War Logs is average at its best, and mediocre at its worst, and, at least in my opinion, is not worth its current price tag, nor is it an RPG that I would recommend to people looking for a great RPG experience. If, however, you still want to give the game a go, do what I did, and buy it on sale for really cheap. If I had to give it a rating, the most I would give it would be a 5/10.

reviewText:
Probably one of the most frustrating yet uninteresting combat systems I've encountered.  Granted, I'm only a couple hours into the game but it's already lost me.  Your companions are next to useless, walking pylons at best, and you spend the majority of most battles leaping around the battlefield or blocking a flurry of blows in order not to get stunlocked.  I don't mind a challenge, Darksouls/Demonsouls are difficult games but there you at least feel like you lost a fair fight.  This game is just tedious.

I'm going to refrain from commenting on the story, haven't experienced enough to give it a fair shake.  However, so far the majority of the quests have been fairly bland in nature (talk to person A or find enough of part B) which are usually solved by walking around talking/clicking on everything until it says you did what you're supposed to.  A few of the quests appear to have some branching paths, which I regard as a good effort, but ultimately aren't really used that effectively and end up being fairly bland.

I might go back and give it another shot at some point, but at the moment I'm glad I only spend $5 on this.

reviewText:
Mars: War Logs is an indie rpg developed by Spiders who recently brought us Bound by Flame. Both games look exciting first, but suffer from certain problems which break the gameplay.

Pros:
There are still a few parts of the game, that may persuade the player to give a chance to the product. The graphics are okay, there is not much to see, but overall the places and people are believable, however do not expect anything fancy. The game kicks off better as it progresses later. I liked the soundtrack in the main menu, which gives the mood. In the early fights also the combat feels good, I had the feeling that something good will come. There are customization options also, which are somewhat in-depth. You can reinforce your gear, both weapons and armor for example with different materials. There are also options to make things out of junk, like medpacks, ammo, etc. The story and dialogues are consumable, nothing really poetic or anything, but it is still one of the better parts of the overall experience. You also have some optional choices which will influence your reputation.

Cons:
And, here comes the cons, because the game has a lot of them. As I got involved into bigger and harder fights I started to see clearly how the combat system cannot handle them. When you face more than 3 enemies at the same time it is starting to get difficult to plan your moves. The target system is not working as intended, and without it you can hardly keep track the movement of the enemy. Usually I get about half a minute before Innocence is incapacitated and all the enemies rush at me. The best tactic is to flee, but there is simply not enough room to do so. The skills also need time to activate, and as the opposite fighters are moving fast, it is almost impossible to use them due to interruption. Overall combat is a mess, nothing more. Also the are problems with the corpses. After some fights I needed to search after the bodies, because they stuck into the wall, and cannot be seen right away. The places looks tiny, corridor-like and they feels alike. The theme itself is not that bad, but is not a rule that each of the sections need to look almost the same.

Overall, I can recommend this title only to those who are really die-hard fans of the rpg genre and have the patience for this.

My Opinion:
OVERALL: 6.5/10
Graphics: 7/10
World Design: 7/10
Gameplay: 6/10
Sound: 7/10
Replay Value: 6/10

I liked the soundtrack in the main menu, which gives the mood. In the early fights also the combat feels good, I had the feeling that something good will come. There are customization options also, which are somewhat in-depth. You can reinforce your gear, both weapons and armor for example with different materials. There are also options to make things out of junk, like medpacks, ammo, etc. The story and dialogues are consumable, nothing really poetic or anything, but it is still one of the better parts of the overall experience. You also have some optional choices which will influence your reputation.

Cons:
And, here comes the cons, because the game has a lot of them. As I got involved into bigger and harder fights I started to see clearly how the combat system cannot handle them. When you face more than 3 enemies at the same time it is starting to get difficult to plan your moves. The target system is not working as intended, and without it you can hardly keep track the movement of the enemy. Usually I get about half a minute before Innocence is incapacitated and all the enemies rush at me. The best tactic is to flee, but there is simply not enough room to do so. The skills also need time to activate, and as the opposite fighters are moving fast, it is almost impossible to use them due to interruption. Overall combat is a mess, nothing more. Also the are problems with the corpses. After some fights I needed to search after the bodies, because they stuck into the wall, and cannot be seen right away. The places looks tiny, corridor-like and they feels alike. The theme itself is not that bad, but is not a rule that each of the sections need to look almost the same.

Overall, I can recommend this title only to those who are really die-hard fans of the rpg genre and have the patience for this.

My Opinion:
OVERALL: 6.5/10
Graphics: 7/10
World Design: 7/10
Gameplay: 6/10
Sound: 7/10
Replay Value: 6/10

reviewText:
Where to start this review of 'Mars: War Logs'. I understand that I have only play just under 20minets. But just hear me out.

This game was Relese in 2013. Expectations where high. But i do under stand the RPGs are really big games to build

As a pc gamer, I was expecting this game to be good from that trailer that Spiders Studios release. But this is where it has taken as complete U-Turn.

Play with as mouse and keybourd like that majoraty of PC plays. We began this game with as avrage cut scene to get some back story, befoer handed the controls. After going through 5mins of base story that explains who this character taht you will be getting the story through. We meet the character that you play.

Starting out where i can now move it began to fall apart. I can see veay clearly that this game was 100% desihned for a controler not keybourd and mouse. normal that is not a really big problem for me but this game just felt really clunky through all the animation blending and hot the character respoind to the commands.

Combat was very basic only need about 3 keys to fight Strick, Block and Block Breaking. A very simple fighting game style, but I felt it need something more something to stand alone from other RPG's. But saddly i had to stop after finishing of the first guy.

After completeing just the little bit I was done.

Texture where very low even on high I can see all the detail in the 512X512 maps. I was hopeing that they would have pushed it a little more.

Animations Felt like it was on the second pass of the Animation stage and need more time spent on. Considering there are lot of closes ups on faces and the lip sinking was off.

Controls really clunky, if going to play it controler you may get better game play.

Over all if your RPG fan maybe try it if you have finished all other games from AAA companys. If your looking to buy it there are a lot better RPGs out there than this one. That is why i would NOT Recommend this on PC.

reviewText: The game feels like the early 2007 alpha of a much better game to be released in late 2008. The environment design is strong, but the game itself is nothing special at all. There is only one type of gun, one type of melee weapon, and combat is very repetitive: dodge, attack, block, counter-attack. There is a crafting system that adds some value to the repetition of looting glowing crates and piles of junk, but it isn't especially robust. The principal voice actor is not strong and subtitles are poorly written. Run-of-the-mill scripting and frequent grammatical errors lead the voice actors to give bad line readings. Voice recording direction seems nonexistant, as they stuck with bad and awkward takes. Some elements just feel erroneous and low-budget; the leg animations for walking are awkward and unrealistic, for example. Legs sort of swing outward and roll forward. Really basic animation elements like these being punted contributes to the unfinished feel. Poor lip-synch and a lack of transition animations between sneaking, walking, slow walking, and sprinting seem to be a function of the low budget and small studio. Overall, this ambitious game does not deliver on its promises, which is really a shame.

reviewText: Why do I like this game? Probably just because I love games that allow you to be the one to make the main character's moral decisions and influence the game's final ending. I beat the game pretty quickly despite the fact that I had to replay multiple parts, and I didn't love the combat, though it was still fun. I found the few characters that were actually developed to some degree to be quite interesting, and the ability to influence the final outcome, and who lives and dies is just something I always enjoy in an rpg.\nWhat's wrong with it? For one dialog is confusing, it's not like in mass effect which gives you, good bad and neutral, in fact it makes little distinction obvious, at times I felt like there was no difference in the choices I was given, and what irrirated me the most was when I clicked an option, but what the character said seemed to be nothing like what the option said. Also as I said before, combat was relatively fun and challenging but nothing to write home about.

reviewText:
First: it's a fun game. It's worth $5 and 15 hours, but don't buy it unless it's on sale.

This is a case of a game not having the resources required to meet its vision.  The core idea behind the game is good, if not entirely gripping:  you take the role of a typical hero on Mars, deciding the fate of its people and factions.  The area design is decent: combats are interesting and there's a certain limited amount of exploring to do.  The environments and character models are visually appealing, but there are far too few of them. The entire game, apart from one area at the end, uses almost all the same object models (doors, walls, boxes, piles of junk, etc).

The skill design is decent: there are actual choices to be made that affect how your character approaches combat.  There are a few choices to be made, story-wise, but it never feels like they really have an impact.

If you're looking for another Mass Effect, this isn't it, although it tries to be.  If you're looking for 15-20 hours of solid gameplay, go for it.

reviewText: Your first impression will be that this game was made on an extremely tight budget.  The voice acting was pretty bad, the animations were anything but smooth, and while the graphics aren't bad, they're not good either. All that being said, this is a satisfying game as long as you're not expecting a mind-blowing experience.  You can genuinely feel for some of the characters and the story is very interesting, even though its rather simple. It is apparrent that the developers put all of what they had into this game, it just wasn't enough to make it great. Also as a side note, the combat system is rather frusterating at times but it doea have a satisfying punch behind it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Its a pretty good game, not disimilar to start wars knights of the old repbulic and mass effect.
It has a nice resource system, scavenging parts, and upgrading weapons and armour. Equally it has a choice driven story with actions changing the game progression. The combat is pretty fun, although once you have the mechanics down it feels the same every time. Theres also a leveling system although its not as intuitive as it could easily have been, and the explanations of how it works are fairely poor.
The game suffers from some very basic visuals, and poor oversight in its development, such as when I spared some people and it stated id killed them in the diary.
Equally, some points of the plot are very poorly written, to the extent that on the spot you could come up with more feasible dialogue.
During cutscenes or dialogue exchanges you can also notice the seams where bits are played based on your choices, which kind of kills the atmosphere. And the dialogue is very limited, with very few available exchanges or choices.
Perhaps the most damning fact is the game is brutally short. For the time iv played it i would expect to be no more than a quarter of the way through it. It feels like it could have been so good, and at times you actually become interested in whats going on, but the development is so shallow, and as soon as you find something interesting the game rushes onto something else.
Had I paid full price, this would be a down vote and id be pretty angry. But given I got it cheap on sale, and that it is a pretty small publisher im pretty happy with it.
If you can get it cheap, go for it. Otherwise id avoid it.

reviewText:
First: it's a fun game. It's worth $5 and 15 hours, but don't buy it unless it's on sale.

This is a case of a game not having the resources required to meet its vision.  The core idea behind the game is good, if not entirely gripping:  you take the role of a typical hero on Mars, deciding the fate of its people and factions.  The area design is decent: combats are interesting and there's a certain limited amount of exploring to do.  The environments and character models are visually appealing, but there are far too few of them. The entire game, apart from one area at the end, uses almost all the same object models (doors, walls, boxes, piles of junk, etc).

The skill design is decent: there are actual choices to be made that affect how your character approaches combat.  There are a few choices to be made, story-wise, but it never feels like they really have an impact.

If you're looking for another Mass Effect, this isn't it, although it tries to be.  If you're looking for 15-20 hours of solid gameplay, go for it.

reviewText: Mars: War Logs is a decent game and well worth the buy.

reviewText: Mars: War Logs piqued my interest right from the start. This indie role-playing game boasts a unique setting and world to explore. The game has plenty of action, but also provides customization through skill trees and crafting.Both of those aspects are nice, but don't feel like fully fleshed-out concepts. I find myself wishing the game was longer, not only because it's a bit on the short side, but because I want to learn more about the fascinating places and characters introduced in the story. This game feels like a great introduction to this universe and I hope to see more.  It could use a bit more polish and variety, but the game remains fun depsite the rough edges and is certainly worth playing.

reviewText: Your first impression will be that this game was made on an extremely tight budget.  The voice acting was pretty bad, the animations were anything but smooth, and while the graphics aren't bad, they're not good either. All that being said, this is a satisfying game as long as you're not expecting a mind-blowing experience.  You can genuinely feel for some of the characters and the story is very interesting, even though its rather simple. It is apparrent that the developers put all of what they had into this game, it just wasn't enough to make it great. Also as a side note, the combat system is rather frusterating at times but it doea have a satisfying punch behind it.

reviewText:
Ok, I'll give a recommend, but just barely and it isn't because the graphics are washed out and lifeless. It's because the story was uninspiring. I lost interest in it about 3/4 of the way through. But there are some redeeming factors in the game:
1. Boss battles are challenging
2. The loot is finite which makes crafting ever so important
3. And finally the combat is very atypical.

There are no real guns/weapons in the game. You can fashion a nailgun into a weapon but thats the only firearm in the game. However, you can make grenades and mines. You get different types of melee weapons that can be modified to enhance combat and your stats. Your armor is modified in the same way. But the most important combat is done using technomancy which is basically the ability to wield electricity and shockwaves.

The skilltree is huge and I was only able to fill 2/4 of the branches so choose wisely on your path.
The side quests pay very well in experience, but you'll find yourself asking why you accepted this mission (oh right, the XP).

The ending was very forgetable as were most of the characters. Play it for the combat not the story.
5/10

reviewText:
At 12 hours of play time and a sale price, I found this game worth it.

Twelve hours of gameplay was nice, because the clunkiness of the game overall might have outworn its welcome past that. The clunkiness includes voice acting, set design, and combat. Sadly, this short play time also means that the characterization of characters was pretty rushed, especially the companion Mary. So, the game could have been longer with better story and characterization or better gameplay, and I'd likely recommend it at full price if that were the case.

What I did like was the setting and overall story, which means I'm looking forward to the sort of sequel in the works, Technomancer.  I did have fun with the gameplay more when I got into the full swing of the Techromancer powers. I liked the ability to craft armor, weapons, health packs, explosives, however this could have all been fleshed out more.

I also particularly liked the titular premise, the game being the War Logs of the aptly named character Innocence. I think that shows some storytelling promise from Spiders.

If they learned from this game, I'm excited to see the results of their sort of sequel, Technomancer. If they got about the same results with better graphics, I'll likely wait until that drops below $10 too.

reviewText:
So just finished this game (only 18 hours start to finish so short game) and its a bag of mixed feelings on it.

The Good:
The idea, premise, and even setting of game is spectacular and draws you in. You want to like this game
The story is good but also bad (thats explained in the bed section)

The Bad:
The combat in this game sucks huge. The timing is off and the UI is clunky. Many time syou will enter combat to find out you have no companion because he/she is stuck in the entrace still.
-As said above, story is mixed bag of good and bad. Why its that is it makes these huge leaps forward in time with no warning or exlaination. One character literally went from hating me and wanting to kill me, to questioning her faith, to being in love with me, IN ONE CONVERSATION. So you end up doing adouble take and wondering what the hell just happened.
-Thats the problem, the writers knew where they wanted to take the story, and its a good story, but instead of flowing from start to finish its jump jump jump and often in those juumps your left wondering how such a huge change happened.
-Maps/zones are quit small in size and because of that you find yourself loading into combat befor eyour compaion joins in

Over all I would give this game a 9/10 on potential
but a 5/10 on delivering and meeting potential
The concept is sound and appealing
They just needed better writers and more back story and lore to discover

reviewText:
First of all I really enjoyed this game.

It's not made with a huge AAA budget, and you can't expect the graphics to be like one either, but it's definetley decent.
What did it for me was the great atmosphere, the setting and some nice quests.
This is for me like many of those hidden gems that could come out as a cult classic in the future like Vampire:Bloodlines, The Witcher 1 and more.

Everything is not perfect, the camera view can be a bit clunky, but if you take it for what it is, and don't be judgemental from the start, I think you will be in for a great experience.

Well worth reccomendig!

After this I started following Spiders-games studio and found a couple of other also very good games in Of Orcs and Men (developed in a co-production with devs Cyanide) and A Bound of Flame.

reviewText:
Alright, this is a short game, so it's up to you and what you feel like playing. However, there's high replayability since there are several paths to follow that lead to different endings (altough for that purpose, I highly recommend that you save prior to key conversations, as they do matter a lot in this game and the outcome).

The thing is... the combat sucks. Like, big time. But if you get hooked by the story, it's bearable and you can get used to it.

The game's got pretty interesting things actually, it does a good job at imagining a distopian futuristic Mars, and lets you build your hero/antihero with an fair enough skilltree. Not to mention that you can romance someone in it, as long as you're not a ♥♥♥♥ at a specific point in the story.

All in all, yes I do recommend it BUT keep in mind that the combat is real crap and that the game's a bit rough around the edges. AND buy on sale or bundled only.

reviewText:
For whatever reason Mars: War Logs makes me feel like it’s coming from one of those hungry new developers that have something to throw out into the industry and make a noise. Mars: War Logs when going head to head with some of the bigger developers and publishers seems more like a poor man’s answer to Mass Effect. It comes away with a mixed bag of features that if you are not looking for King Lear you may find enough here to keep you entertained amongst the Hodge podge of entertainment values. This sci fi rpg style game has a nice enough mix to it in regards to gaming that players of some of the table top cyberpunk or other sci fi games will find some entertainment here.

Mars: War Logs takes place a century after some world changing event. The red planet is in turmoil and war. Water is now the most prized resource causing out right war for its control. In the middle of all this players start out as a prisoner of war. Shipped off to a POW camp the interactions begin to get rather tense here and it is here that you soon discover this is not a game for kids. When they warn of adult content and sexual innuendos they are not kidding. A young character almost runs afoul of a prison gang in the sand showers; they want to ♥♥♥♥ the lad. The dialogue is pretty straight forward about it as is the actions of the characters on screen.

The main character is multi skilled and like any good story is soon on a grand adventure. It’s in a world where the outcome really won’t make a huge impact; it’s more about making a crap situation into a tolerable one. Along the way players the character is developed more by not only the choices set forth, but also as the players choose different skills and perks to customize the character. There is also a crafting system that allows for creation and modifications of equipment. Early in the game you are able to craft either injections like a health pack, or ammunition which allows the player to create ammo for their weapons.

Under the skill tree there are only a few options to choose to branch from they are Renegade, Combat or Technomancer. Each one has interesting builds offering different play styles and strengths and weaknesses. Every time the character levels up the player will have skill points that they can spend to better the characters abilities. There are also equipment slots; players can customize the looks and stats of equipment for a better overall RPG experience.

The first part of the game is understandably easy, the first encounter acts as a tutorial when you mix it up with some fellow prisoners. Later on the enemy types get much harder to deal with and it takes some strategy to take them on. Depending on your play style there are some sections of the game that stealth comes in handy. You can even go so far as to say stealth is very important in some areas. Trying to max out the renegade skills having to do with stealth is a big help in these sections; especially if the player wants to try their hand at some of those stealth kills.

Story and voice acting are not too bad; they fit the game style well. There are times throughout the story where the character dialogue is cut off, and they do not speak what is painfully obvious the full line they are supposed to speak. So if you run into this, having the sub titles on may be of some assistance. While on this subject in regards to story, avoid the temptation to jump past the story dialogues and cut scenes, a lot of the game is more enjoyable while having the story play out for you. Voice acting I suspect was done more on an individual actor by actor basis, rather than the actors running the scene together and being in the moment. For the most part it sells, it’s not stellar voice overs but it is not awful either.

Combat in the game comes down to a lot of maneuvering, especially if the player draws the attention of several enemies at once. They will swarm you and attack as they see fit. They won’t line up and come at you in order to make it easy for you. Oh no, some strategy and hit and run tactics are in order here. After taking an enemy out don’t forget to search them for useful items.

Mars: War Logs is worth a go as long as you understand out of the gate it’s not a triple -A -title. But as a gamer, a true gamer, you may just find yourself some entertainment here.
